awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Molecular Engineering of Bio-orthogonal Stabilized Alpha Helices
awd_abstract_narration:
1553860 
Thurber, Greg    

Novel molecular engineering strategies are rapidly enabling the development of unique bio-inspired molecules for materials, separations, drug, and medical imaging agent applications. However, these natural molecules often degrade at the conditions necessary for their use, such as in acidic or basic pH solutions when purifying a product or in the body where enzymes degrade the compounds before they can reach their therapeutic target. By using synthetic organic molecules to stabilize these biological materials, the agents can be engineered with both vast complexity and high stability. Furthermore, by choosing an appropriate chemical technique, high-throughput methods can be developed to rapidly select useful molecules from libraries of millions of compounds. This work will support basic research into the fundamental properties of these semi-synthetic materials and enable applied research to develop novel compounds for diverse applications. 

This CAREER proposal will combine novel synthetic linkers, non-natural amino acid (NNAA) incorporation, and bio-orthogonal chemistry with directed evolution to engineer stabilized helices with unique targeting properties. Aim 1 of this proposal will characterize a novel series of azide-alkyne stabilized alpha helices that possess unique chemical, imaging, and pharmacokinetic properties and are compatible with cell surface directed evolution. This arrangement only requires one type of NNAA in the peptide backbone to reduce complexity and increase overall incorporation efficiency. The longer linker can be engineered with a functional handle for attachment to beads, fluorescent dyes, radiolabels, or pharmacokinetic modifiers. This modular design enables these molecules to be used in multiple applications including separations, intracellular targeting, and imaging. Aim 2 of the proposal will capitalize on the bio-orthogonal chemistry to select novel helices. A site-specific linkage is introduced to select for molecules that will retain binding while attached to the linker. This proposal will alleviate the current development bottleneck by screening millions of novel stabilized helices for new therapeutics, imaging agents, and separations components.  Engineering functionally diverse stabilized peptide and protein structures will impact several fields including the chemical industry, biomedical engineering field, pharmaceutical industry, and medical community. 

To grow the pipeline of highly qualified and diverse engineering students to fulfill these jobs, a science-focused outreach program will be created for students from local under-resourced schools in the Detroit area. Multiple interactions with students from predominantly under-represented backgrounds facilitate hands-on activities directly related to molecular engineering research. These students will visit the University of Michigan for interactive sessions to enhance their scientific understanding and encourage them to pursue science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields.

This CAREER award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

por.por_cntn:
The CAREER award, Molecular Engineering of Bio-orthogonal Stabilized Alpha Helices, has been completed by the PI, Greg Thurber, accomplishing both aims of the proposal. The purpose of this proposal was to determine the optimal molecular properties for both therapeutic and molecular imaging agent applications of peptides that are chemically cross-linked to constrain them in a stabilized alpha helix. These helical peptides are more protease resistant in vivo, generally have higher binding affinity by locking them in the bound conformation, and can increase membrane permeability for intracellular applications by increasing intramolecular hydrogen bonding along the peptide backbone. This proposal tested the impact of these molecular properties on binding and distribution and developed a novel peptide engineering method.  In the first aim, the impact of molecular properties on the multiscale distribution of molecular imaging agents was characterized. Aim two developed a new method for engineering novel stabilized peptides.

For Aim 1, a series of single and two-helix bundles were synthesized and tested for binding affinity and targeting specificity. Trade-offs were observed where increased helicity could improve binding affinity and protease stability but also non-specific sticking. Precise quantification enabled the identification of receptor binding in non-target tissue for an application developing imaging agents for the early detection of type 1 diabetes. Using insight from the previous studies, it was possible to design a blocking dose that saturated the non-target tissue while sparing the target tissue to significantly improve specificity for measuring insulin-secreting beta cell mass.

For Aim 2, a new method for engineering stabilized helical peptides was developed by combining non-natural amino acid incorporation with bio-orthogonal click chemistry. Briefly, a library of bacteria expressing a series of randomized peptides on their surface was fed non-natural amino acids (NNAAs) to incorporate into the sequence. Once these peptides were displayed on the bacterial surface, the NNAAs were cross-linked using click chemistry that is specific to the synthetic functional groups. The stabilized alpha helix library was then incubated with the target of interest, and the bacteria binding the target were isolated by magnetic or fluorescent cell sorting. The DNA was isolated and sequenced to identify high affinity and/or specific binders. The utility of this method was demonstrated by screening for high affinity binders to the MDM2 protein, a well-characterized model system to develop the technology. Serendipitously, the highest affinity clone contained a disulfide bond, generating a bicyclic structure which likely contributed to the increased binding affinity. The details of this approach are now published so the method can be utilized to develop novel stabilized helical peptides.

The CAREER award also supported outreach to under-resourced middle and high school students in the downtown and greater Detroit area. Through this program, over 100 students were transported to the University of Michigan campus as part of ?A Day in the Life of a Chemical Engineer? and ?Be a Brain Surgeon for the Day.? The former program involved live science demonstrations by the PI, a discussion on how chemical engineers work on products that are part of student?s everyday life, a poster session led by undergraduates who presented on a variety of chemical engineering careers, and a tour of the engineering campus. The latter program focused on the development of near-infrared intraoperative imaging through a series of hands-on science activities. Faculty, postdocs, and graduate students developed 8 stations related to the physics of waves and fundamentals of fluorescence with slinkies, an electric guitar, laser pointers, near infrared cameras, and a culminating ?surgery? on a fluorescent gel phantom. Formative evaluation indicated students were engaged and improved their awareness of engineering topics, career opportunities, and courses involves.

 


Last Modified: 02/14/2023
Modified by: Greg Thurber
